title: Mixed Hearing Loss with Acute Tympanic Membrane Perforation
chief_complaint: I had a sudden decrease in hearing in my right ear last week after a severe infection. I am still feeling pain and pressure in that ear.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden worsening of hearing in the right ear last week following a severe ear infection.
problem_summary.course: Chronic history of ear problems since childhood with repeated infections and bilateral hearing loss. Acute exacerbation occurred last week resulting in spontaneous tympanic membrane rupture.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss, currently worse in the right ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Aural pain, aural pressure, and likely drainage (due to rupture) in the right ear.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient wears hearing aids bilaterally but is experiencing significant difficulty with the right ear due to the recent event.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Resolve the infection and pain; assess damage to the ear.

history.present_illness: The patient presented with a sudden decrease in hearing in the right ear following a severe infection last week. The infection resulted in a spontaneous tympanic membrane rupture.
history.otologic_history: History of ear problems since childhood, repeated infections, and hearing loss in both ears.
history.patient_goals: Evaluation of acute changes in the right ear.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows a profound mixed hearing loss rising to moderately severe in the low-to-mid frequencies, then sloping to severe in high frequencies. Left ear shows a flat mild sloping to moderate sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear SRT is consistent with the profound loss, with very poor word recognition (10%). Left ear SRT agrees with PTA, with moderate difficulty in word recognition (70%).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear revealed a flat tympanogram (Type B) with a large ear canal volume, consistent with a perforation. Left ear revealed a normal tympanogram (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ear reflexes (ipsilateral and contralateral) were absent. Left ear ipsilateral reflexes were present; left contralateral reflexes were absent.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with asymmetric hearing loss. The left ear exhibits a stable mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss with fair word recognition. The right ear demonstrates a profound mixed hearing loss with very poor word recognition, significantly exacerbated by an acute middle ear pathology. Tympanometry confirms a tympanic membrane perforation in the right ear (large ear canal volume).
counseling_points: You have a perforation (hole) in your right eardrum, likely caused by the severe infection you experienced.
The large volume reading in the test confirms the hole in the eardrum.
We are referring you to an ENT specialist immediately for management of the infection and the perforation.
Please use the prescribed antibiotic ear drops exactly as directed to clear the infection.
Do not wear your hearing aid in the right ear until the doctor confirms the infection is gone and the ear is dry.
Keep the right ear dry; use water precautions when showering.
We will need to re-evaluate your hearing in about a month to see if the eardrum heals on its own or if surgery is needed.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is accustomed to hearing loss but is distressed by the new acute pain and sudden drop in hearing on the right side.
You should mention that you have had 'bad ears' your whole life.
Express concern about whether the hole in your eardrum will heal.
